page.title: 04NORTH DOWNS. WOODLANDS
page.content: There are two types of managed woodland in the area. The largest is coppicing, mainly sweet chestnut for palings, fence posts and logs. Each year one tenth of an estate is cut and left to regrow. Oak and ash standards are left to mark areas. In the N.E. corner is a Forestry Commission area under conifers, grown for building. Most farm woodland and a lot of coppiced land is let to private shoots and these are managed to facilitate the breeding of pheasants. The farm woodlands consist of magnificient beeches, oaks, yew, wild cherry and silver birch. There are also typical chalk-loving trees, such as spindle, wayfarers tree, alder and spurging blackthorn.
